title: CoME: An Unlearning-based Approach to Conflict-free Model Editing
author: Dahyun Jung (Korea University), Jaehyung Seo (Korea University), Jaewook Lee (Korea University), Chanjun Park (Korea University), Heuiseok Lim (Korea University), ...
relevance_why: The framework for conflict-free knowledge editing can inspire methods for improving audio-language model capabilities, particularly in managing outdated knowledge or biases.
background: Enhancing the reliability of large language models by integrating new, accurate knowledge while systematically removing outdated or conflicting information.
contribution: CoME introduces an unlearning approach to effectively remove outdated knowledge during model editing, achieving improved accuracy in knowledge updates and enhanced model reliability.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods struggled with outdated knowledge interfering with newly integrated data, often resulting in performance drops.
technical_comparison.novelty: CoME simultaneously unlearns obsolete knowledge while incorporating new knowledge, significantly reducing knowledge conflicts without compromising existing linguistic capabilities.

key_innovation: Combines knowledge unlearning with model editing to ensure linguistic features are preserved while outdated information is effectively discarded.
real_world_impact: This method improves the accuracy and reliability of language models, which is crucial for preventing misinformation in automated systems like chatbots and content generators.
limitations: Lacks detailed exploration of trade-offs between unlearning and maintaining unrelated knowledge, which might require further optimization.

new_terms.counterfact: **Counterfact** refers to knowledge that contradicts the usual facts or common beliefs – a useful mechanism for training models on alternative scenarios.
new_terms.unlearning: **Unlearning** is the process of intentionally removing previously acquired knowledge from a model, aiming to address issues such as bias or outdated information.

open_sourcing: The code is available at https://github.com/ekgus9/COME.
